biospec_descr.textblock: 5 mL of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) will be collected in this study at one time point.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to obtain cerebrospinal fluid from healthy children already
      undergoing a lumbar puncture procedure at New York Presbyterian Hospital, to act as healthy
      controls when compared to children with late infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis
      (LINCL), a fatal neurodegenerative disease.

clinical_study.brief_title: Collection of Cerebrospinal Fluid in Healthy Children

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Males and females, ages 2 yrs to 8 yrs

          -  Children already undergoing a lumbar puncture procedure for clinical or diagnostic
             purposes

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Presence of any significant neurological diseases, as judged by the co-investigators

          -  Presence of any significant medical conditions including cancer

study_pop.textblock:
Subjects will be healthy controls (children ages 2 years to 8 years) undergoing a lumbar
        puncture at New York Presbyterian Hospital, for clinical care purposes. They will be
        inpatients and outpatients.

facility.name: Weill Cornell Medical College / New York Presbyterian Hospital

clinical_study.official_title: Collection of Cerebrospinal Fluid in Healthy Children

overall_official.affiliation: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

authority: United States: Clinical and Translational Science Center

primary_outcome.description: The primary study endpoint is the metabolic profiling of 32 samples of cerebrospinal fluid from healthy subjects, in comparison to 32 samples of CSF from children with LINCL, to determine whether there are biomarkers found in the cerebrospinal fluid that are associated with LINCL.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
